Converts the contents of the bitset to a string. Uses {{c|zero}} to represent bits with value of {{c|false}} and {{c|one}} to represent bits with value of {{c|true}}.

The resulting string contains {{c|N}} characters with the first character corresponds to the last ({{c|N-1}}{{sup|th}}) bit and the last character corresponding to the first bit.

{{rrev|until=c++11|
All template type arguments need to be provided because function templates cannot have default template arguments. Overloads {{v|2-4}} are provided to simplify the invocations of {{tt|to_string}}:
@2@ Uses the default allocator {{lc|std::allocator}}.
@3@ Uses the default character trait {{lc|std::char_traits}} and the default allocator {{lc|std::allocator}}.
@4@ Uses the default character type {{c/core|char}}, the default character trait {{lc|std::char_traits}} and the default allocator {{lc|std::allocator}}.
}}

===Parameters===
{{par begin}}
{{par|zero|character to use to represent {{c|false}}}}
{{par|one|character to use to represent {{c|true}}}}
{{par end}}

===Return value===
@1@ The converted string.
@2@ {{c|to_string&lt;CharT, Traits, std::allocator&lt;CharT&gt;&gt;(zero, one)}}.
@3@ {{c|to_string&lt;CharT, std::char_traits&lt;CharT&gt;, std::allocator&lt;CharT&gt;&gt;(zero, one)}}.
@4@ {{c|to_string&lt;char, std::char_traits&lt;char&gt;, std::allocator&lt;char&gt;&gt;(zero, one)}}.

===Exceptions===
May throw {{lc|std::bad_alloc}} from the {{lc|std::basic_string}} constructor.

===Notes===
Since C++11, functions templates can have default template arguments. {{lwg|1113}} removed the helper overloads {{vl|2-4}} and added the corresponding default template arguments in {{vl|1}}.

===Example===
{{example
|code=
#include &lt;bitset&gt;
#include &lt;iostream&gt;

int main()
{
    std::bitset&lt;8&gt; b{42};
    std::cout &lt;&lt; b.to_string() &lt;&lt; '\n'
              &lt;&lt; b.to_string('*') &lt;&lt; '\n'
              &lt;&lt; b.to_string('O', 'X') &lt;&lt; '\n';
}
|output=
00101010
**1*1*1*
OOXOXOXO
}}
